I have a degree in philosophy, and another degree in anthropology, but in all honesty, I didn't become a leftist until arguing with 'libertarians' and anarcho-capitalists on the internet.  What a shock it was to realize that they don't actually believe in freedom. At least, they don't believe in freedom for anyone other than the wealthy owners of land and natural resources. Everyone else has no choice but to sign over all of their freedom and individuality for someone else's profit, just so that they can have access to the basic necessities of life. It is all just so that they can survive.  But land and natural resources are naturally accessible to anyone. Why should any one individual have exclusive owenership of it at the expense of others? How is that right maintained? You see, the only way for it to be maintained is through a system of coersive government. By limiting the freedom of others to live, they preserve their own freedom and 'right' to exploit others for their own private benefit.  The wealthy make profit, using our labor and our bodies to do so, and all we get out of the involuntary deal is to continue living, and to continue working, for them. There is no alternative, so how could it be voluntary? Not only that, but the people we work for are the same people we must pay in order to continue living. They pay us less than the value of the products we produce, and then they turn around and sell those same products right back to us for more than we were paid to produce them. The products we produce and the products we buy are the same, and never do we truly benefit. All of the benefit goes to the wealthy. This is exploitation.  There is no choice but to give others authority over ourselves, when individuals have the right to own land and natural resources. We would starve without them to sustain us. We are entirely dependent on them. Yet, they have sole power to determine our fates. We are not in charge of our own lives or llivelihoods we rely on people whose only purpose is to make profit for themselves. They don't care about their workers. The workers are useful tools for them. They are replaceable. Of course, it is not so easy for the workers who have been replaced and who have no money to sustain their lives with.  The wealthy are free to live in luxury precisely because no one else is free at all. I never knew this before engaging in debate online, and I've read Marx many times. It's definitely valuable. But it's also valuable to be educated in philosophy. It only arms you against the ignorant. Knowledge is power, just like money is.

The worst part is that I don't feel like I can tell my adviser because there's a heavy stigma associated with leaving academia, and I suspect that my remaining social and professional resources would be pulled if I expressed anything other than a masochistic devotion for my research. And to top it off, academia is this weird paradoxical place--a bastion of liberal values and simultaneously a socially acceptable good old boys club--where poor quality of life for graduate students (e.g., poor pay for tons of work, a culture of silence surrounding the report of workplace-related sexual assault, rampant depression and anxiety) is often the norm. While I appreciate most of what you've said here, as a mathematics professor I have to say at least a few positive words about discovering higher-order truths about chmess. A couple thousand years ago one could easily have taken 'chmess' to be referring to the philosophical musings of Indian gurus about the concept 'zero'. When the Muslim Caliphate entered the picture and combined this concept with a penchant for arithmetic, algebra, and engineering, the foundations of the modern scientific method were born. It may not be a simple matter to see how these two things are connected, but great leaps forward can sometimes be made in mathematics by discovering the best notation to use for discussing a topic. A couple hundred years ago, one could easily have taken 'chmess' to be referring to the esoteric study of formal logic - people arguing about how to argue, when everyone knew that syllogisms were sufficient to handle correct argumentation. In the 1930's Alan Turing (building on the indispensable but often unappreciated work of others before him) used this arcane form of mathematics to build computers that, in addition to building the technological foundation of everything we use that has any kind of electronic component, literally shortened the second world war by a matter of years. Today, one can easily take 'chmess' to be referring, literally, to some abstract variant of chess which nobody has, is, or even could ever play, and yet solving it can have direct or indirect implications for all manner of technological progress (some of which has indisputable social implications), from the question of whether or not quantum computers will turn out to be fundamentally different to classical computers to whether or not it is even feasible to hide private communications from spying eyes in the long run.  Now I understand very well that this may not be your cup of tea, but dismissing even a subject like category theory (which has been referred to by many mathematicians as 'generalized abstract nonsense') as obviously useless seems to me to be short-sighted at best.

The problem with academic philosophy isn't leftism. It's very specifically _postmodernist_ leftism.  Postmodernism has given us a few cool contributions to the arts, but its contributions to philosophy and (especially) the sciences have been about 90% malign gibberish. Even the few postmodernist philosophers who've had worthwhile ideas (Foucault, Deleuze, Butler) write in the most maddeningly obscure jargon and prose that looks like it still requires translation.   And the good postmodernists have mostly just reinvented the wheel anyway, independently coming to the same conclusions as social anarchists like Proudhon/Kropotkin/Goldman decades after they explored identical ideas, but with fewer references to literature and esoteric forms of psychoanalysis.  The social anarchist Iain McKay for instance wrote a sterling critique of right-wing libertarianism and 'anarcho'-capitalism in the late 90s in his Anarchist FAQ, all 4,000 pages of which he's made available for free online.
